prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would. What integer $n$ satisfies $0\le n<19$ and $$-200\equiv n\pmod{19}~?$$
solution: Noticing that $190\equiv0\pmod{19}$ and $-200+190=-10$, we can say that  \[-200\equiv n\pmod{19}\]if and only if  \[-10\equiv n\pmod{19}.\]This is not in the range $0\leq n<19$, but adding 19 again gives \[9\equiv n\pmod{19}.\]The answer is $n=\boxed{9}$.
gpt_response:
Counting up from $0$ by $19$ until we reach a number that is $200$ less than a multiple of $19$:
$$0, 19, 38, 57, 76, 95, 114, 133, 152, 171 \rightarrow -200 = 19(−11)$$
So, the integer $n$ that satisfies $0\le n<19$ and $-200\equiv n\pmod{19}$ is $\boxed{9}$.
solution_prompt:
Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to 9?: Counting up from $0$ by $19$ until we reach a number that is $200$ less than a multiple of $19$:
$$0, 19, 38, 57, 76, 95, 114, 133, 152, 171 \rightarrow -200 = 19(−11)$$
So, the integer $n$ that satisfies $0\le n<19$ and $-200\equiv n\pmod{19}$ is $\boxed{9}$.
